item.title: Paper Trails: The Art of Processing Archival Collections at Green Library, East Wing
item.description: Every archival collection that Stanford Libraries acquires must be processed before it can be made available for research. The expertise, thought, and care that goes into processing archival collections often occurs behind-the-scenes. Using the John Perry Barlow papers as a throughline, this exhibit explores the art of processing archival collections.

item.title: TAML Bootcamp Part 1/6 at Hybrid
item.description:
This is a hybrid event. Please register for each part separately.

TAML Bootcamp Part 1 / 6

The Software and Services for Data Science (SSDS) Text Analysis and Machine Learning (TAML) Bootcamp is geared towards the complete beginner who seeks to learn basic Python and learn the basics of text analysis and machine learning. However, all are welcome! In this first session, you will learn how to navigate the Google Colaboratory environment for programming Python and basic coding syntax. We will teach you: 

  • How to save data in Python's memory through a process called variable assignment
  • Differences between functions, arguments, and methods
  • Core data types and structures for storing them
  • How to import .txt and .csv files
  • Error messages and how to find help

Workshop materials:

  • https://eastbayev.github.io/SSDS-TAML/intro.html
  • https://eastbayev.github.io/SSDS-TAML/fall2022/1_How_to_use_this_book.html
  • https://eastbayev.github.io/SSDS-TAML/fall2022/2_Python_environments.html
  • https://eastbayev.github.io/SSDS-TAML/fall2022/3_Basic_Python_syntax.html

item.title: TAML Bootcamp Part 2/6 at Hybrid
item.description:
This is a hybrid event. Please register for each part separately.

TAML Bootcamp Part 2 / 6

In Part 2, you will learn how to use the pandas Python library to:

  • Learn about numeric data frames
  • Subset dataframes by rows and columns and by logical condition
  • Compute basic summary statistics

You will also be introduced to the matplotlib and seaborn libraries where you will learn to make

  • Histograms
  • Boxplots
  • Scatterplots

Workshop materials:

  • https://eastbayev.github.io/SSDS-TAML/fall2022/4_Numeric_data_wrangling.html
  • https://eastbayev.github.io/SSDS-TAML/fall2022/5_Data_visualization_essentials.html

item.title: Library Tour for New Student Orientation (NSO) at Green Library, East Wing Entrance
item.description: Stanford University Libraries welcomes new students and their families to tour Green Library on September 20th. Tours will be offered at 10am and 2pm, and will last approximately 25 minutes. Tours will start at the East Wing Entrance, which is next to the Red Fountain.

item.title: Library Tour for New Student Orientation (NSO) at Green Library, East Wing Entrance
item.description: Stanford University Libraries welcomes new students and their families to tour Green Library on September 20th. Tours will be offered at 10am and 2pm, and will last approximately 25 minutes. Tours will start at the East Wing Entrance, which is next to the Red Fountain.

item.title: TAML Bootcamp Part 3/6 at Hybrid
item.description:
This is a hybrid event. Please register for each part separately.

TAML Bootcamp Part 3 / 6

In Part 3, you will learn basic machine learning terminology and practice its application through:

  • An ordinary least squares (OLS) regression "by hand" example
  • A logicstic regression example

You will also learn how to prepare text for use in machine learning algorithms through use of:

  • Document encoding
  • Dotument-term matrix
  • Bag of words model
  • Term-frequency inverse document frequency (TF-IDF)

Workshop materials:

  • https://eastbayev.github.io/SSDS-TAML/fall2022/6_Core_concepts_vocabularies.html

item.title: TAML Bootcamp Part 4/6 at Hybrid
item.description:
This is a hybrid event. Please register for each part separately.

TAML Bootcamp Part 4 / 6

In Part 4, we will focus on specific aspects of standardizing text prior to analysis for a single document and for a corpus of United Nations Human Rights Council documents, including:

  • Standardizing casing and spacing
  • Removing punctuation and stop words
  • Tokenizing text
  • Lemmatizing/stemming
  • Part of speech tags

Workshop materials:

  • https://eastbayev.github.io/SSDS-TAML/fall2022/7_English_text_preprocessing_basics.html

item.title: Web Archives as Research Data Workshop at Hohbach Hall 126
item.description: Whether it's politicians changing their policy platform, government turnover, or the evolution of discourse and norms within online communities, web archiving holds great potential as a way to gather research materials and data about the modern world. Join us Wednesday, September 21 from 1:30-3 for a hybrid workshop on a new tool for web archiving, Browsertrix Cloud, that combines ease of use with the capacity to capture rich, interactive sites, including social media. This workshop will combine a hands-on demo of Browsertrix Cloud with a discussion about Stanford Libraries' current policies and practices around web archiving and data, with an eye towards how we can update those practices to better serve scholars' needs. After the workshop, participants will have the opportunity to join a pilot group that will get access to Browsertrix Cloud through the end of 2022, and give us feedback about how they use it. All scholars (including graduate students) interested in working with websites as data, as well as interested subject-area librarians and other library staff are welcome!

item.title: An Introduction to the Stanford Geospatial Center & ArcGIS Online [NGSO] at Mitchell Earth Sciences
item.description:
As part of New Graduate Student Orientation events sponsored by Stanford Libraries, The Stanford Geospatial Center will present an orientation to their resources, as well as an hands-on Introduction to ArcGIS Online, for Beginners.

The first part of this event will orient users to the resources and services of the SGC, including software provisioning and support as well as access to data sources like Planetscope Monitoring, a daily, global, 3 meter resolution, multispectral image.

The second part of the event is designed to introduce new spatial data users to ArcGIS Online, part of an ecosystem of software and data that Stanford Libraries' provide to researchers for creating, managing analyzing and presenting their spatial data.

No previous experience with spatial data is necessary.

Attendees are welcome to attend this Webinar, in person, at Branner Earth Sciences Library, if they prefer.

item.title: Branner Earth Sciences Library Open House at Mitchell Earth Sciences
item.description: Welcome to Stanford! As part of the new student orientation week for Fall 2022, the Branner Library and Stanford Geospatial Center will host an open house. Drop by anytime 10am-12pm Thursday September 22nd for coffee, donuts, and a tour of the Branner Library, Map collections, and Stanford Geospatial Center.

item.title: Find Maps, Create StoryMaps! at Mitchell Earth Sciences
item.description: Stanford Libraries has over 300,000 maps in their collections, 40,000 of which are digitized, which means a lot of content just waiting for you to do something amazing with it. Join Andria Olson, map librarian at Branner Earth Sciences Library & Map Collections, as she guides you through how to navigate our online catalog, SearchWorks, to hunt down the map of your dreams. After finding the map (or a bunch), she will then provide a demonstration on how to access and use StoryMaps to create a dynamic, multimedia story using historic maps.

item.title: Signing Ceremony for the Establishment of the Taiwan Resource Center for Chinese Studies at Lathrop Library
item.description:
Please join us for a signing ceremony to commemmorate the establishment of the Taiwan Resource Center for Chinese Studies (TRCCS). University Librarian Michael A. Keller and Director-General Shu-hsien Tseng of the National Central Library of Taiwan will offer some remarks on the significance of the TRCCS and formally sign the agreement between Stanford Libraries and the National Central Library inaugurating the center. A short reception will follow, with tea and light snacks provided.

The Taiwan Resource Center for Chinese Studies is a cooperative project intended to promote international exchange in the fields of Chinese studies and Taiwan studies. Through this project, the National Central Library of Taiwan (NCL) has partnered with over forty libraries at worldwide research institutions, including Stanford University. As part of the cooperative agreement, the NCL will provide TRCCS partner institutions with annual donations of print and audio-visual materials published in Taiwan as well as IP-based access to shared e-resources. These resources will be displayed in a location at Stanford's East Asia Library designated with a plaque featuring the logo of the Taiwan Resource Center for Chinese Studies in English and Chinese.

item.title: Planet.com Demo at Mitchell Earth Sciences
item.description:
Planet is the leader in the current "small sat" revolution in Earth imaging. With a growing constellation of 200+ "Doves," Planet is able to image the Earth's landmass at 3m pixel resolution, once every day. This high cadence, medium-high resolution imagery is well suited to monitoring applications, semantic segmentation and traditional remote sensing applications.

Stanford Geospatial Center's Stace Maples will provide a high level overview of the Planetscope data subscription, including how to search for and access the data available to Stanford Researchers, through the Stanford University Library.

item.title: Data Discovery with Stanford Earthworks at Mitchell Earth Sciences
item.description: Spatial data search with Stanfords geo data portal, Earthworks. Find, download, and visualize spatial data quickly by keyword or location. Look up metadata including licensing and copyright use. Copy data citations. Download raw data for desktop or grab web service links for online mapping. This demo will be led by David Medeiros the Geospatial Instruction & Reference Specialist of the Stanford Geospatial Center.

item.title: TAML Bootcamp Part 5/6 at Hybrid
item.description:
This is a hybrid event. Please register for each part separately.

TAML Bootcamp Part 5 / 6

Now that you have familiarity with the basics, Part 5 will show you how to create supercharged natural language processing pipelines using functionality from the spaCy and textaCy Python libraries.

Workshop materials:

  • https://eastbayev.github.io/SSDS-TAML/fall2022/8_spaCy_textaCy.html

item.title: TAML Bootcamp Part 6/6 at Hybrid
item.description:
This is a hybrid event. Please register for each part separately.

TAML Bootcamp Part 6 / 6

Finally, learn to model abstract concepts in text data using the BERTopic algorithm!

Workshop materials:

  • https://eastbayev.github.io/SSDS-TAML/fall2022/9_BERTopic.html

item.title: Overreach and Overreaction: The Downward Spiral in the U.S.-China Relations at Green Library, Bing Wing
item.description:
Stanford Libraries and the Stanford Center on China's Economy and Institutions are pleased to present the 2022 Dr. Sam-Chung Hsieh Memorial Lecture featuring Professor Susan Shirk who will be speaking on Overreach and Overreaction: The Downward Spiral in the U.S.-China Relations.  This is an in-person event.

Why did China abandon its successful foreign policy of restraint and shift toward confrontation and unchecked control over its own society? Surprisingly the shift began under Hu Jintao's collective leadership (2002-12). Under the personalistic leadership of Xi Jinping the trend has intensified. Those who implement Xi's directives compete to outdo one another, provoking an even greater global backlash. To counter China's overreach, the worst mistake the rest of the world, and the United States in particular, can make is to overreact. Understanding the domestic political drivers of foreign policy in both countries can help us stem the downward spiral in relations.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------

Susan Shirk is Chair of the 21st Century China Center and research professor at the UC San Diego School of Global Policy and Strategy. Shirk's book, China:  Fragile Superpower helped frame the policy debate on China in the U.S. and other countries. Her articles have appeared in leading academic publications in political science, international relations, and China studies. She previously served as deputy assistant secretary of state (1997-2000) responsible for U.S. policy toward China, Taiwan, Hong Kong and Mongolia. She is director emeritus of the UC Institute on Global Conflict and Cooperation and founded the Northeast Asia Cooperation Dialogue, an unofficial forum for discussion of security issues. Shirk is a graduate of Mt. Holyoke College and received her PhD from M.I.T.

---------------------------------------------------------------------------

The family of Dr. Sam-Chung Hsieh donated his personal archive to the Stanford Libraries' Special Collections and endowed the Dr. Sam-Chung Hsieh Memorial Lecture series to honor his legacy and to inspire future generations. Dr. Sam-Chung Hsieh (1919-2004) was former Governor of the Central Bank in Taiwan. During his tenure, he was responsible for the world's largest foreign exchange reserves, and was widely recognized for achieving stability and economic growth. In his long and distinguished career as economist and development specialist, he held key positions in multilateral institutions including the Asian Development Bank, where as founding Director, he was instrumental in advancing the green revolution and in the transformation of rural Asia. Read more about Dr. Hsieh.

item.title: CIDR Intro to R at Hybrid
item.description:
This introductory workshop is geared towards those who would like to get started with R or need to brush up on their skills. You will learn how to use R, RStudio, how to create objects in R, how to work with different data types, how to read tabular data into R and how to subset tables.

This is a Hybrid workshop! Upon registering you can select to attend in-person (Velma Denning Room, 120F Green Library) or via Zoom. 

Prerequisites:

  • None

Before the workshop, be sure to download and install:

  • R: https://cloud.r-project.org/
  • RStudio Desktop Free: https://www.rstudio.com/products/rstudio/download/

Workshop materials:

  • https://cengel.github.io/R-intro

item.title: CIDR Intro to Python at Hybrid
item.description:
This workshop provides an introduction to the Python programming language: basic syntax, variable assignment, functions, data import, and how to understand error messages and find help. You will learn enough Python to perform common tasks and explore the rich environment of Python packages available. 

This is a Hybrid workshop! Upon registering you can select to attend in-person (Velma Denning Room, 120F Green Library) or via Zoom. 

Prerequisites:

  • None

Workshop materials:

  • https://eastbayev.github.io/SSDS-TAML/intro.html

item.title: Remembering Partition: 75 Years of Independence-Partition at Green Library, Bing Wing
item.description: Come join us as we commemorate 75 years since the Partition of the Indian subcontinent with a panel discussion and presentation about the collaboration between The 1947 Partition Archive and Stanford Libraries to make almost 10,000 oral histories of Partition witnesses available online for streaming. The panel will feature local Partition witnesses; Founder of The 1947 Partition Archive, Guneeta Singh Bhalla; Fisher Family Director of Stanford Global Studies and Associate Professor in Theater and Performance Studies, Jisha Menon; and South Asian Studies Curator at Stanford Libraries, C. Ryan Perkins.

item.title: CIDR R Data Wrangling at Hybrid
item.description:
This workshop is for those who know the basics of R and would like to get started working with their research data. We will look into the tools that R provides to manipulate and explore tabular data, including reshaping, summarizing, and plotting. You will learn how to use the tidyverse package, in particular dplyr, tidyr, and ggplot.

This is a Hybrid workshop! Upon registering you can select to attend in-person (Velma Denning Room, 120F Green Library) or via Zoom. 

Prerequisites:

  • CIDR Introduction to R workshop (or equivalent knowledge).

Before the workshop, be sure to download and install:

  • R: https://cloud.r-project.org/
  • RStudio Desktop Free: https://www.rstudio.com/products/rstudio/download/

Workshop materials:

  • https://cengel.github.io/R-data-wrangling

item.title: Teaching the aspiring researcher: an educational workshop [Gear-Up] at Sapp Center for Science Teaching and Learning
item.description:
Since 2020, every summer term the Libraries have partnered with several different undergraduate research programs on the Stanford campus. These programs are designed to help underrepresented students achieve their goals of entering into graduate school. With the shift towards more and more computational based research, helping these students learn about basic coding and programming is a critical skill. In this workshop you will hear from some of the students from these programs talk about their experiences in the program, how they used the information they learned to complete their projects, and how you can apply these teaching practices in your own work. This event will have live, hands-on teaching demonstrations, and will also cover content inspired by the computational program known as The Carpentries.

Instructor: Zac Painter

This is a hybrid workshop. Upon registering you can select to attend in-person at the Li & Ma Science Library in the SAPP Center or via Zoom.

item.title: Photovoice: A method to amplify communities' voice through participatory action research [Gear-Up] at Sapp Center for Science Teaching and Learning
item.description:
Participatory Action Research (PAR) is a study method that allows researchers and participants to look into specific topics or problems through an iterative cycle of research, dialogue, action, and reflection, using a range of qualitative and quantitative techniques. At the core of PAR resides the recognition of the value of local and traditional knowledge through direct involvement of community members in the research process.

Photovoice is a participatory photography methodology that uses participatory photography to empower participants to reflect on their personal experiences around a research question and share their perspectives through storytelling and focus groups. In this sense, participants act as co-researchers by interpreting the meaning behind their stories for the researchers. providing a participatory framework for the elicitation and representation of social and cultural knowledge.

In this workshop, participants will learn about how to design and prepare a photovoice project, as well as to analyze related qualitative and quantitative data related using a mixed-methods software, using environmental justice data.

Instructor: Isabel Carrera Zamanillo

This is a hybrid workshop. Upon registering you can select to attend in-person at the Li & Ma Science Library in the SAPP Center or via Zoom.

item.title: An Introduction to the Stanford Geospatial Center & ArcGIS Online [Gear-Up]
item.description:
The Stanford Geospatial Center will present an orientation to their resources, as well as an hands-on Introduction to ArcGIS Online, for Beginners. The first part of this event will orient users to the resources and services of the SGC, including software provisioning and support as well as access to data sources like Planetscope Monitoring, a daily, global, 3 meter resolution, multispectral image. The second part of the event is designed to introduce new spatial data users to ArcGIS Online, part of an ecosystem of software and data that Stanford Libraries' provide to researchers for creating, managing analyzing and presenting their spatial data. No previous experience with spatial data is necessary.

Instructor: Stace Maples

This is a virtual workshop. You will receive a Zoom link after registration.

item.title: Justice, Equity, Diversity, and Inclusion (JEDI) Fair at Green Library, Bing Wing
item.description:
Stanford Libraries is hosting its 2nd annual Justice, Equity, Diversity, and Inclusion (JEDI) Fair to highlight social justice projects, collections, and efforts happening within the Libraries and at other departments across the Stanford campus.   
 
Hear featured speakers, see live demonstrations of the Know Systemic Racism (KSR) website and highlights from the Libraries existing social justice collections, attend a new book release and signing by co-authors Stephen Shames and Ericka Huggins, and pick up lots of great giveaways.

Following the Fair, starting at 4:30 pm in Green Library's Bender Room (5th floor), join co-authors Stephen Shames and Ericka Huggins of the newly released book, Comrade Sisters: Women of the Black Panther Party, and former Black Panther Party members M. Gayle Asali Dickson and Rosita Thomas for a panel discussion.

RSVPs for the Panel Discussion is appreciated. Book sales and signing will follow.

Come expecting to leave empowered!

Check back for updates.

item.title: Panel Disussion: New book release, "Comrade Sisters: Women of the Black Panther Party" at Green Library, Bing Wing
item.description:
Many of us have heard these three words: Black Panther Party.

Some know the Party's history as a movement for the social, political, economic, and spiritual upliftment of Black and indigenous people of color – but to this day, few know the story of the backbone of the Party: the women. It's estimated that six out of ten Panther Party members were women. While these remarkable women of all ages and diverse backgrounds were regularly making headlines agitating, protesting, and organizing, these same women were building communities and enacting social justice, providing food, housing, education, healthcare, and more to the people. Comrade Sisters is their story.

Please join Stanford Libraries as we host what is sure to be an exciting discussion featuring co-authors Stephen Shames and Ericka Huggins of the newly released book, Comrade Sisters: Women of the Black Panther Party. Mr. Shames and Ms. Huggins will be joined by two other former Black Panther Party members, M. Gayle Asali Dickson and Rosita Thomas for the discussion, which will take place in Green Library's Bender room, 5th floor.

The panel discussion will begin at 4:30 pm following the JEDI (Justice, Equity, Diversity, and Inclusion) Fair, (2 – 4 pm).

RSVPs for the Panel Discussion is appreciated.

Book sales and signing will follow.

__________

Speakers:

Ericka Huggins is an activist, former political prisoner, and leader in the Black Panther Party. She has devoted her life to the equitable treatment of all human beings, beyond the boundaries of race, age, culture, class, gender, sexual orientation, ability, and status associated with citizenship. For the past 40 years, she has lectured across the country and internationally. She spent 14 years in the Black Panther Party, and eight years as Director of the renowned Oakland Community School (1973-1981).

Stephen Shames has authored 15 monographs, and his images are in the permanent collections of 40 museums and foundations. His work is dedicated to promoting social change and sharing the stories of those who are frequently overlooked by society. His two previous Panther books are Power to the People: The World of the Black Panthers by Stephen Shames and Bobby Seale (Abrams,2016) and The Black Panthers (Aperture, 2006).

M. Gayle Asali Dickson is an ordained minister and served as Pastor of the South Berkeley Congregational Church (SBCC), United Church of Christ, in Berkeley, CA from 1998 to 2006. Prior to serving as pastor of SBCC, Gayle Asali was a graphic artist for the Black Panther Party (BPP) Newspaper and drew for its back pages under the name Asali. She also served as a preschool teacher at its Oakland Community School using art as a tool to teach cognitive skills to preschoolers. She gives of her time whenever possible to the wider community. Read more.

item.title: CIDR Python Data Wrangling at Hybrid
item.description:
This workshop teaches basic data manipulation with Python using the Pandas library, and will cover topics such as loading data into and out of a Pandas DataFrame, performing basic data cleaning, preparation, and analysis, and visualizing relevant aspects of a dataset.

This is a Hybrid workshop! Upon registering you can select to attend in-person (Velma Denning Room, 120F Green Library) or via Zoom. 

Prerequisites:

  • CIDR Introduction to Python (or similar knowledge). (If you need a refresher, check out A Byte of Python (https://python.swaroopch.com/).

Workshop materials:

  • https://github.com/sul-cidr/Workshops/tree/master/Data_Manipulation_with_Python

item.title: Understanding Messy Time Series Data [Gear-Up] at Sapp Center for Science Teaching and Learning
item.description:
This workshop introduces you to working with messy time series data. We will teach you about common pitfalls for data sourcing and continuity through use of Gross Domestic Product (GDP) as a rough measure of global societal well-being. The first hour will introduce GDP to discuss these issues when different reporting agencies, incentives, and approaches are considered.

The second hour will dive into code that compares results of different models based on endogenous and exogenous data filling methods, along with useful guidance on tools for vectorized approaches to your data. Basic Python proficiency is assumed if you want to run the examples, but all are welcome to attend and learn about data robustness issues and how the concepts might be useful to apply to your own data and research.

If you want to learn basic Python, visit us at https://ssds.stanford.edu to register for the upcoming Text Analysis and Machine Learning (TAML) Bootcamp (September 19, 21, and 23) or Introduction to Python workshop (October 5). 

Instructors: Anthony Weng and Evan Muzzall

This is a hybrid workshop. Upon registering you can select to attend in-person at the Li & Ma Science Library in the SAPP Center or via Zoom.

item.title: CIDR R Visualization at Hybrid
item.description:
Data visualizations are essential to effectively communicate research. This workshop will review three base plots in R (histogram, boxplot, and scatterplot) before introducing you to the ggplot2 package. 

This is a Hybrid workshop! Upon registering you can select to attend in-person (Velma Denning Room, 120F Green Library) or via Zoom. 

Prerequisites:

  • CIDR Introduction to R workshop (or similar experience).

Before the workshop, be sure to download and install:

  • Download R: https://cloud.r-project.org/
  • Download RStudio Desktop Free: https://www.rstudio.com/products/rstudio/download/

Workshop materials:

  • https://github.com/sul-cidr/data-visualization-ggplot2

item.title: CIDR Python Visualization at Hybrid
item.description:
Data visualizations are essential to effectively communicate research. This workshop will introduce you to three basic visualizations using the Python matplotlib and seaborn libraries: histogram, boxplot, and scatterplot. 

This is a Hybrid workshop! Upon registering you can select to attend in-person (Velma Denning Room, 120F Green Library) or via Zoom. 

Prerequisites:

  • CIDR Introduction to Python workshop (or similar knowledge)

Workshop materials:

  • https://eastbayev.github.io/SSDS-TAML/fall2022/5_Data_visualization_essentials.html

item.title: CIDR Python Text Analysis at Hybrid
item.description:
This workshop will introduce you to working with text data using the spaCy and textacy Python libraries. You will learn to effectively streamline text preprocessing, understand word tokenization, sentence segmentation, part-of-speech tagging, and named entity recognition using a single document (a short excerpt from H.G. Wells's A Short History of the World) and across a corpus of legal documents. 

This is a Hybrid workshop! Upon registering you can select to attend in-person (Velma Denning Room, 120F Green Library) or via Zoom. 

Prerequisites:

  • CIDR Introduction to Python workshop (or similar experience)

Workshop materials:

  • https://github.com/sul-cidr/Workshops/tree/master/Text_Analysis_with_Python

item.title: CIDR R Text Analysis at Hybrid
item.description:
Are you interested in analyzing collections of novels or journal articles? Do you want to understand patterns across collections of tweets or other social media data? In this workshop, we'll learn how to import, clean, and analyze collections of text with R using several standard text mining libraries. 

This is a Hybrid workshop! Upon registering you can select to attend in-person (Velma Denning Room, 120F Green Library) or via Zoom. 

Prerequisites:

  • The Introduction to R CIDR workshop or equivalent experience.

Before the workshop, be sure to download and install:

  • R: https://cloud.r-project.org/
  • RStudio Desktop Free: https://www.rstudio.com/products/rstudio/download/

Workshop materials:

  • https://cengel.github.io/R-text-analysis/

item.title: CIDR Python Machine Learning at Hybrid
item.description:
This workshop provides a gentle introduction to machine learning vocabulary and concepts. You will learn the basics for classifying text and images using the scikit-learn, lime, and tensorflow Python libraries. 

This is a Hybrid workshop! Upon registering you can select to attend in-person (Velma Denning Room, 120F Green Library) or via Zoom. 

Prerequisites:

  • CIDR Introduction to Python workshop (or similar experience).

Workshop materials:

  • https://github.com/sul-cidr/Workshops/tree/master/Intro_to_ML_with_Python

item.title: CIDR R Machine Learning at Hybrid
item.description:
This workshop provides a beginner-friendly introduction to machine learning vocabulary and concepts, quantitative data preprocessing for machine learning, and the SuperLearner R package.

This is a Hybrid workshop! Upon registering you can select to attend in-person (Velma Denning Room, 120F Green Library) or via Zoom.

Prerequisites:

  • CIDR Introduction to R workshop (or similar experience).

Before the workshop, be sure to download and install:

  • R: https://cloud.r-project.org/
  • RStudio Desktop Free: https://www.rstudio.com/products/rstudio/download/

Workshop materials:

  • https://github.com/sul-cidr/Workshops/tree/master/Intro_ML_R

item.title: CIDR Bash and GitHub at Hybrid
item.description:
In the first half of this workshop you will learn how to use the Bash programming language to interface with your computer's operating system and perform basic actions to navigate your file system and create and edit files and directories. In the second half you will apply these principles to use the collaborative version tracking platform GitHub to store your coding projects.

This is a Hybrid workshop! Upon registering you can select to attend in-person (Velma Denning Room, 120F Green Library) or via Zoom.

Prerequisites

  • Basic familiarity with computers

Before the workshop - Mac users

  • Make sure you have the Xcode developer toolset installed. Open a Terminal and type
    xcode-select --install
  • When asked if you want to install the command line developer tools, click "yes/install"

Before the workshop - Windows users

  • Install git/gitbash by clicking here: https://git-scm.com/downloads
  • Download the file and double-click it to run the installer

Workshop materials: coming soon

item.title: CIDR GitHub Pages at Hybrid
item.description:
In this workshop you will build on the skills you learn in CIDR Intro to Bash and GitHub to create free static webpages for your CV, projects, and other activities.

This is a Hybrid workshop! Upon registering you can select to attend in-person (Velma Denning Room, 120F Green Library) or via Zoom.

Prerequisites

  • CIDR Bash and GitHub (or equivalent knowledge)

Workshop materials:

  • https://github.com/sul-cidr/gh-pages-2021
